captions.text:
It's one of a kind,
and the engine sounds great.
It's just a wonderful feeling.

My boat has the most important parts
from the most outstanding BMW ever.
The BMW 507.
A good friend of mine told me

that there was supposedly a BMW boat
powered by a BMW 507 engine.
Then I started searching to find that boat.

Of course, it was unrestored.
It was badly damaged.
It had been kept in a barn for years and years.

It was intact, all the parts were there,
but we had to completely restore it.
Then I found an expert in southern Germany
who restores Rivas.

And he helped me
completely restore the outer hull

and paint the boat
in the original colours.

I had a professional upholsterer do the interior
just as it was back when it originally came out.

We had an expert
restore the entire instrument panel as well.
No question, it's absolutely unique.
Rambeck is the oldest wharf in Bavaria.
HISTORICAL ACCOUNT

In the 1950s, after the war,
we said, "Let's build a little speedboat."

And there was this big company in Munich
that still exists now, BMW.

They said, "Hey, a boat like that
with our engine, now that would be something."
I was still in school back then.

At the beginning
I didn't really pick up on what was going on,

that it was going to be a hi-tech boat
with the same engine as the ultimate car.
Then we received the emblems.
From the BMW 507, the flat kidney grille.
That in itself was poetry to behold,

and the fact that we at Rambeck got that
was sensational.
And then the steering wheel and the engine.

It was class all around.
That speedboat was the BMW boat.
It had to be one of a kind.

But it had been a very, very long time
since we heard anything about that boat.

And then this guy contacts us,
a total madman.

It's the only way to put it.
Who does that to themselves?

I mean, who goes out and restores a boat
that's a complete wreck?
I'm really glad that ship docks here,
that it is driven here in these waters
where it can be showcased

for people to see
what BMW and Rambeck achieved.

I really like driving cars,
classic cars and convertibles.
But cruising around in that boat
with its BMW engine, that really fascinates me.
I would be happy if someday

I managed to find a BMW 507
Roadster to complement my boat.

Of course, that's not easy,
because they are very rare.
But maybe I'll manage.
I'm Felipe Garcia, and that's my story.

title: The only BMW 507 boat appeared again.

James Bond!!﻿

comments.text: Timeless Design ﻿
comments.author: George Ven

comments.text:
Great video and lovely boat and while this is the only one of this Rambeck 
style, there were actually three boats built.  BMW did two others with 
Abbate at the same time, one was the Helm Glockler boat and the other was 
the Motomar boat.  A German living in Italy had Abatte restore the Helm 
Glockler boat after Herr Glockler passed in 1993 and I understand it is in 
the USA now.   I have pictures of BMW showcasing these boats to the public 
in the late 50s.  ﻿
comments.author: Robert Willis

comments.text:
+George Ven Hi George,  I agree this boat is stunning, as are the other 
two, I presume you have seen the pictures.  I have to beg to differ though 
- the Abattes were made with BMW's involvement and as I mentioned, BMW took 
these two Abatte boats around Europe showcasing their wares.  Funnily, I 
have also heard from BMW Classic about the Abatte boats and their 
involvement, so I suppose it's down to who you talk to.  I remember when I 
first heard the story about the first Abatte 507 boat, that was the only 
one that existed and now we have three :-).  Like you, I found these boats 
really very interesting, but my research was a long time ago and while the 
Abatte boats do not have the side grills, they do have many of the other 
things you mention, including 507 clocks, tool kits etc.  At the end of the 
day, they are all very special boats and I am sure the owners know what 
they have. 

You are correct, most of the lovely 401/507 boat engines made went to 
industrial use or as I heard, a few went into cars - with the necessary 
changes of course.  I never have been really able to find out exactly how 
many were made, although 80 - 85 seems to be the considered answer, but of 
that sum only 3 were used for these wooden boats and I understand one went 
into an Italian fishing boat - pretty interesting fisherman I am sure:-)
comments.author: Robert Willis

comments.text:
Saw this boat at Villa d' Este concours this year and is trully 
breathtaking! I spoke with the staff of the guys of BMW Classic department 
there and they said this is the only one specially built for BMW AG.
Indeed the 507 boat reference because on top of the V8 marine engine, the 
hull was also built with the steering wheel, radio and instruments and of 
the 507... ohhh and the famous side grills!  
I have made a hobby of learning about this lovely artifact since I saw it 
and no doubt this was a oneoff have prototype to test the V8 marine 
engines. Sadly some marine engines were converted to industrial engines and 
others found their way into motor cars.      
I understood that the Abatte boats  were build on behalf of private 
parties, even though they share the same engine, but not the accessories 
from the 507.
I myself have a Fletcher BMW powered boat, its nothing that special but 
also part of the amazing BMW Marine history!
comments.author: George Ven
